title: Question asking as a tool for novice computer skill acquisition
proctitle: CHI '91: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems

authors.name: Marc M. Sebrechts
authors.institution: Department of Psychology, The Catholic University of America, Washington, DC

authors.name: Merryanna L. Swartz
authors.institution: Vitro Corporation, 14000 Georgia Ave, Silver Spring, MD

references.text: Aaronson, A. & Carroll, J. M. The answer is in the question: A protocol study of intelligent help. Behavior and Information Technology, 6, (1987), 393-402.

Chi, M. T. H., Bassok, M., Lewis, R., Reimann, P., & Glaser, R. Self-explanations: How students study and use examples in learning to solve problems. Cognitive Science, 13, (1989), 145-182.

Fischer, G. Enhancing incremental learning processes with knowledge-based systems. In H. Mandl & A. Lesgold (Eds.). Learning issues for intelligent tutoring systems. Springer-Verlag, New York, NY, 1988.

Lehnert, W.G. The process of question answering. Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, HUlsdale, NJ, 1978.
Miyake, N. & Norman, D. A. To ask a question, one must know enough to know what is not known. Journal of Verbal Learning and Verbal Behavior, 18, (1979), 357-364.

Robertson, S. P, & Swartz, M. L. Questions reflect the knowledge utilized during procedural skill learning. In Proceedings of the Ninth Annual Conference for the Cognitive Science Society (Seattle, WA, July 16-18), Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Hillsdale, NJ, , 1987, 16-19.

Sebrechts, M. M., Marsh, R. L., & Furstenberg, C.T. Integrative modeling: Changes in mental models during learning. In S. P. Robertson, Zachary, W. & Black, J. B. (Eds.). Cognition, computing, and cooperation. Ablex Publishing Corporation, Norwood, NJ, 1990, 338-398.
